question: Pain in throat, cough after eating capsicum, paneer. Took medicines. Had allergy attack second time. Reason?after eating mixed vegetable of Capsicum and paneer, my son got pain in throat , unable to drink smoothly, continuously coughing, doc says it was allergy . Today again it pop-up. We are confused. He had Wysolone, and Histac (150 mg) and inj Effcoulin 100 mg, why should allergy attacked second time within 24 hrs after showing sign of improvement? pl advice next steps..thx Rajendra
answer: It is possible that your son is experiencing an allergic reaction to the capsicum and paneer. Allergic reactions can vary in severity and may involve symptoms such as throat pain, coughing, difficulty swallowing, and difficulty breathing. The symptoms may improve with treatment, but they may also recur if exposure to the allergen continues.If your son is experiencing recurrent allergic reactions after eating capsicum and paneer, it is important to avoid these foods in the future to prevent further allergic reactions. You may also want to consider discussing your son's symptoms with an allergist or immunologist, who can perform allergy testing to determine which specific substances are causing the allergic reactions and help develop a plan to manage the allergies. In the meantime, it is important to follow your doctor's instructions for treating the allergic reactions and to seek medical attention if the symptoms worsen or do not improve.

question: Suggest supplements for G6PD deficiencyhi!im maren from the philippines. my 1 1/2 yr old son is g6pd deficient.what food should i feed him?i m still breastfeeding. should i also avoid the the foods to be avoided by g6pd deficients. does it helps if we exposed him to sunlight every morning?
answer: Foods that include MENTHOL, like candies, toothpastes, biting gums, mouthwash, etc., is required to be avoided by people along with G6PD deficiency. LEGUMES for instance fava beans, kidney legumes, and lima beans must not be consumed. Also, soy pinto beans, and foods containing soy, similar to tofu, miso or soy healthy proteins, are a strict no-no. Peanuts, licorice, alfalfa plants sprouting up, and products that contain these food types should be avoided continuously. Foods that carry ascorbic acid or nutritional C in large quantities shouldn't be consumed. Artificial inorganic dyes, especially the color pink, should be avoided by of those with G6PD deficiency. Refined sugars, corn syrup, and light flour, should be refrained from inside diet, as the person is deficient in the respective enzymes was required to break down these foodstuff. Drinking tonic mineral water or eating bitter melon is forbidden for individuals suffering from G6PD lack. Some additional foods that ought to be refrained from are earth-friendly peas, field peas, black-eyed peas, and a few edible pods like Chinese language pea pods and perfect peas. Lentils, as well as some beans which include black beans or refried beans ought not to be eaten. Avoid Chinese meals, as they contain herbal remedies like Rhizoma coptidis, margarita, Flos lonicerae, along with Calculus bovis, that might possibly trigger a hemolytic tv show. Packaged foods may contain some things that provoke a reaction, while should be avoided. These food types include margarine, jarred greens dressings, canned fish plus meat, hot dogs, ready-made meat, sausages, tinned sauces, potato chips, low-fat cheeses, and various sauces like Worcestershire gravy or sweet and wrong sauce. Read the constituents in processed foods mindfully before buying or consuming the products. Prevention is always the very best cure. Take care!

question: Suggest supplements for G6PD deficiencyhi!im maren from the philippines. my 1 1/2 yr old son is g6pd deficient.what food should i feed him?i m still breastfeeding. should i also avoid the the foods to be avoided by g6pd deficients. does it helps if we exposed him to sunlight every morning?
answer: G6PD deficiency is a genetic disorder that affects the body's ability to produce an enzyme called glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD). This enzyme plays a critical role in maintaining the health of red blood cells. People with G6PD deficiency are at risk for developing anemia, a condition in which the body does not have enough healthy red blood cells to carry oxygen to the body's tissues.There are a few things you can do to help manage G6PD deficiency in your 1 1/2 year old son:Follow a diet that is low in fava beans and other foods that contain high levels of an oxidant called oxidized nucleosides. These foods can be harmful to people with G6PD deficiency because they can cause the destruction of red blood cells. A list of foods to avoid can be found here: https://www.nhlbi.nih.gov/health-topics/g6pd-deficiency#dietContinue breastfeeding your son. Breast milk is the perfect food for infants and provides all the nutrients they need for healthy growth and development.It is not necessary to expose your son to sunlight every morning, as there is no evidence to suggest that sunlight has any specific benefit for people with G6PD deficiency. However, it is important to ensure that your son gets enough vitamin D, which is essential for bone health and can be obtained through diet and/or supplements.It is also important to work closely with your healthcare provider to develop a management plan for your son's G6PD deficiency. This may include taking supplements, such as folic acid, and avoiding certain medications that could be harmful to people with G6PD deficiency. Your healthcare provider will be able to advise you on the best course of action for your son based on his specific needs and medical history.

question: What are the precautions to be taken before having polio vaccine?I have dermatomyositis and my baby grand-daughter is about to have her vaccinations which include the oral polio vaccine.  As this is a live vaccine, what precautions should I take as we are meant to avoid contact with people who have just received live vaccines?    Thank you.  Sarah
answer: This is because live vaccines contain a weakened form of the virus or bacteria that can potentially cause infection in people with compromised immune systems.To reduce the risk of infection, it is important to take the following precautions:Wash your hands frequently and avoid touching your face, especially after coming into contact with someone who has recently received a live vaccine.If you must be in close contact with someone who has recently received a live vaccine, try to maintain a distance of at least 3 feet (1 meter).If you are in close contact with someone who has recently received a live vaccine, try to avoid activities that could increase the risk of transmission, such as sharing food or drinks or using the same utensils.If you are in close contact with someone who has recently received a live vaccine, you may want to consider wearing a mask to reduce the risk of transmission.It is important to note that the risk of transmission from live vaccines is generally low, and the benefits of vaccination generally outweigh the potential risks. However, if you are concerned about the risk of infection, you may want to discuss your concerns with your healthcare provider.

question: Are there any natural medication to reduce sugar levels?sugan level is fasting 118 and post meal 145 with by acucheck glco meater ( after taking no sweets like tea, icecream, mithai etc, except seasonal fruit, but not juice),(at present no medicine taken by me ) How to reduce sugar level without medicine. is it symptom of prediabetic or normal
answer: There are several natural ways to help reduce blood sugar levels, including:Eating a healthy, balanced diet: Focus on incorporating whole, unprocessed foods such as vegetables, fruits, and whole grains into your diet. These foods are high in fiber, which can help slow the absorption of sugar into the bloodstream.Exercising regularly: Physical activity can help lower blood sugar levels by increasing the body's sensitivity to insulin. Aim for at least 30 minutes of moderate-intensity exercise, such as brisk walking or cycling, most days of the week.Losing excess weight: Carrying excess weight, especially around the waist, can increase the risk of developing type 2 diabetes. Losing weight through diet and exercise can help lower blood sugar levels and reduce the risk of developing diabetes.Reducing stress: High levels of stress can lead to an increase in blood sugar levels. Try practicing stress-reducing techniques such as meditation, yoga, or deep breathing to help keep blood sugar levels in check.Getting enough sleep: Lack of sleep can disrupt the body's natural balance of hormones and lead to an increase in blood sugar levels. Aim for 7-9 hours of sleep per night to help keep blood sugar levels stable.It is not possible for me to determine whether your blood sugar levels are normal or indicative of prediabetes without more information about your overall health and medical history. If you are concerned about your blood sugar levels, it is important to speak with a healthcare professional for proper evaluation and guidance.

question: What causes nervousness and lack of confidence?I constantly cry when I get nervous, dissapointed, or afraid. Its an everyday thing and affects the way i interact with others. I can't talk to my boss or a professor without choking up and i can't tell people what i like or dislike even without feeling like i need to shed some tears. I wont be sad about anything, i'll just cry, or well, choke up. are there any disorders-besides depression- that could be causing my problem?
answer: There can be many causes of nervousness and lack of confidence, and it's important to note that these feelings are common and normal to experience at times. However, if they are persistent and interfere with your daily life, it may be helpful to speak with a mental health professional. They can help you identify any underlying issues and provide you with strategies to manage your symptoms.It's possible that you may be experiencing anxiety or social anxiety, which can cause nervousness and lack of confidence in social situations. Other potential causes of these symptoms could include past trauma or adverse experiences, low self-esteem, or certain life stressors.It's also worth noting that crying in response to emotions is a normal and healthy way to express and process feelings. However, if you feel that your crying is excessive or disrupting your daily life, it may be helpful to speak with a mental health professional to explore possible causes and develop coping strategies.It's important to remember that it's okay to seek help if you are struggling with your emotions or if they are impacting your daily life. A mental health professional can provide you with support and guidance to help you manage your symptoms and improve your overall well-being.

question: Can marijuana and smoking worsen the alcoholic cirrhosis liver?Hi Doctor, I am a 52 year old female weighing 164lbs and 5'7" tall. About 6 months ago I was diagnosed with alcoholic cirrhosis liver condition caused by drnking much alcohol.  I worry I don't sleep or eat  and suffer from great anxiety. Will smoking or ingesting marijuana make my liver condition worsen? It will help with sleeping, eating and anxiety. I don't know much about marijuana use and need this info.
answer: It is not clear whether marijuana use can worsen alcoholic cirrhosis of the liver. Alcohol is the primary cause of cirrhosis, and heavy alcohol use is known to significantly increase the risk of developing this condition. While marijuana may have some potential benefits for certain medical conditions, it is not a treatment for alcoholic cirrhosis and should not be used as a substitute for evidence-based treatments for this condition.If you have been diagnosed with alcoholic cirrhosis, it is important to avoid alcohol completely and follow the treatment recommendations of your healthcare provider. This may include medications, lifestyle changes, and possibly a liver transplant if the damage to your liver is severe.It is also important to address any underlying mental health issues, such as anxiety, as these can have a significant impact on your overall health and well-being. There are a number of effective treatments available for anxiety, including therapy, medication, and self-care techniques. It is important to work with your healthcare provider to determine the best course of treatment for you.

question: What are the chances of pregnancy in HBV negative wife & HBV positive husband?I have been TTC from past 1.5 years. The blood test resulted all normal for me and for my husband, it is Hepatitis - B positive. Will this is the cause for not getting conceived (Wife being HBV - negative and Husband being HBV - positive) ? What is the solution if we want to conceive?
answer: The risk of transmission of HBV from an HBV-positive man to an HBV-negative woman during pregnancy or childbirth is relatively low, and can be further reduced with proper preventive measures.If you and your husband are planning to conceive and you are HBV-negative, it is recommended that you get vaccinated against HBV before becoming pregnant. This will provide you with immunity to the virus and reduce the risk of transmission to you and your baby.If you are unable to get vaccinated before becoming pregnant, you should discuss the options for preventing transmission of HBV with your healthcare provider. This may include receiving immune globulin and/or antiviral medications during pregnancy.It is also important for your husband to manage his HBV infection by taking his medications as prescribed and practicing safe sex to reduce the risk of transmission to you and any children you may have.If you have been trying to conceive for over a year without success, it is important to consult with a healthcare provider to determine the cause and discuss treatment options. There may be other factors contributing to your difficulty conceiving, such as fertility issues or underlying health conditions. A healthcare provider can help you assess your fertility and discuss options for increasing your chances of conceiving.

question: Can i safely go on amusement park rides with an EF of 40?Hi I am a breast cancer patient, I am currently on Herceptin (I finished 20 rounds of taxol/herceptin then AC). The herceptin has caused my ejection factor to drop to 40, I am currently on meds to increase it so i can resume the herceptin. Can I safely go on amusement park rides with an ef of 40?

They will be able to assess your overall health and advise you on what activities are safe for you to participate in based on your medical history and current condition.

question: What is osteophytic lipping?Hello Dr. What is Osteophetic Lipping? I have been diagnosed to have osteophyetic lipping, and have been suggested to have surgery on my feet. Is it worth having this surgery? My work involves standing over 9hrs a day on my feet and I used to walk a lot, but always in flat sensible shoes. I have a lot of pain in my feet, and cannot do much walking, but job involves standing a lot. Would you kindly advise me on this. Regards Rochan
answer: Osteophytic lipping is a condition where bony outgrowths, called osteophytes, form on the edges of bones in the joints. These outgrowths can cause pain and discomfort, as well as restrict movement. Osteophytes can form in response to wear and tear on the joint, or as a result of other underlying conditions such as osteoarthritis or rheumatoid arthritis.Surgery to remove osteophytes may be recommended if non-surgical treatments, such as physical therapy and medications, have not been effective in relieving pain and improving function. The decision to have surgery should be based on a thorough evaluation by a doctor, and should take into consideration the severity of the condition, the potential risks and benefits of the surgery, and the patient's individual needs and preferences.If you are considering surgery, it is important to discuss your options with your doctor and to carefully weigh the potential risks and benefits. It is also important to keep in mind that surgery is not always successful and may not fully relieve your symptoms. In some cases, lifestyle changes, such as modifying your work activities or wearing proper footwear, may be effective in managing your condition and reducing pain.

question: Q. Is glioblastoma curable?Hello doctor,The patient has glioblastoma cancer, undergone surgery but not operated correctly, taken radiotherapy and chemotherapy, the doctor said chemo tablets are not working, maybe the tumor has formed again so they stopped giving medicine. We are not going anywhere now.
answer: Glioblastoma is a type of brain cancer that is very aggressive and difficult to treat. It is not curable, but treatment can help to slow the progression of the disease and improve the patient's quality of life.After surgery, patients with glioblastoma may receive additional treatment such as radiation therapy and chemotherapy. These treatments can help to kill cancer cells and shrink the tumor, but they do not always succeed in eliminating all of the cancer cells. As a result, the cancer can recur after treatment.If the tumor has recurred and chemotherapy is no longer effective, the treating medical team may consider other treatment options such as clinical trials, targeted therapy, or supportive care. It is important to discuss all treatment options with the medical team and make decisions that align with the patient's goals and values.It is also important to manage symptoms and provide supportive care to improve the patient's quality of life. This may include medications to control pain, swelling, and other symptoms, as well as psychological and social support.

question: Q. What are the chances of HIV transmission through mosquitoes?Hello doctor,Regarding the transmission of HIV by mosquitoes, I have following query. I know the virus does not survive in insects, but what if some mosquito bites a very high viral load HIV-infected person and then bites an uninfected person on his wound, who crushes it on his wound. If the above situation happens at three or four places on his body simultaneously by an HIV-infected mosquito, what is the possibility of HIV transmission by this method?
answer: beyonddcdcdcdc@163.comQ. What are the chances of HIV transmission through mosquitoes?Hello doctor,Regarding the transmission of HIV by mosquitoes, I have following query. I know the virus does not survive in insects, but what if some mosquito bites a very high viral load HIV-infected person and then bites an uninfected person on his wound, who crushes it on his wound. If the above situation happens at three or four places on his body simultaneously by an HIV-infected mosquito, what is the possibility of HIV transmission by this method?There is no risk of HIV transmission through mosquitoes. HIV is a virus that affects humans and other primates, and it cannot replicate or survive in the bodies of insects such as mosquitoes. Mosquitoes do not transmit HIV when they bite humans.In fact, HIV cannot survive outside the body for very long. The virus is fragile and is easily damaged by exposure to air, heat, and light. Therefore, it is not possible for HIV to be transmitted through mosquitoes or any other type of insect.It is important to note that HIV is primarily transmitted through the exchange of bodily fluids, such as blood, semen, vaginal secretions, and breast milk. The most common ways to contract HIV are through sexual contact, sharing needles, and mother-to-child transmission during childbirth or breastfeeding. It is important to practice safe sex, avoid sharing needles, and get tested regularly to reduce the risk of HIV transmission.

question: What could be the possible reasons of getting infected by hbsag?hi i m 7 months pregnant 27 yrs old i m found to be hbsag infected although i was vaccinated in childhood against this infection whereas my husband is hbsag negative how would it affect my child and whta should i do?  what could be the possible reasons of getting infected? plz guide
answer: There are several possible reasons why you may have become infected with the hepatitis B virus, even if you were vaccinated against it as a child:You may have come into contact with the virus through:Sexual contact with an infected personSharing needles or other drug injection equipment with an infected personBeing accidentally stuck with a needle that has been contaminated with the virusYou may have become infected through exposure to blood or body fluids of an infected person, such as through a blood transfusion or organ transplant.You may have become infected through close contact with an infected person in your household, such as through sharing personal hygiene items like razors or toothbrushes.It's important to note that being infected with the hepatitis B virus during pregnancy can increase the risk of your baby becoming infected with the virus. question: Trying to conceive. Negative ovulation kit test. answer: It is possible to have delayed ovulation, which can affect your ability to conceive. Ovulation, or the release of an egg from the ovary, typically occurs around day 14 of a 28-day menstrual cycle, but this can vary from person to person and cycle to cycle. Some people may ovulate later in their cycle, or even outside of their usual menstrual cycle.There are several factors that can affect ovulation, including stress, changes in weight or exercise patterns, certain medications, and underlying medical conditions such as polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS). It's important to talk to your healthcare provider about any concerns you have about ovulation or fertility. They can help you determine the cause of any potential delays and recommend treatment options.If you have been trying to conceive for over a year and have not been successful, it may be helpful to consult with a fertility specialist. They can perform further testing and help you determine the best course of action for you and your partner.

question: What causes pain and difficulty in movement in my arm after a fall?I fell in my basketball game earlier, and I hurt my arm, it s not bruised I don t think, and it s not broken. Although it hurts when I touch it, and slightly move it in certain directions, to top it off it keeps twitching, what could this be? Should I be worried ?
answer: It's possible that you may have strained or sprained your arm as a result of the fall. Strains and sprains are common injuries that occur when the muscles or ligaments in a joint are stretched or torn. Symptoms of a strain or sprain may include pain, swelling, bruising, and difficulty moving the affected limb. Twitching of the muscle may also occur.It's important to take care of a strain or sprain as soon as possible to prevent further injury and promote healing. Resting the injured limb and applying ice to the affected area can help reduce swelling and pain. Over-the-counter pain medications, such as acetaminophen or ibuprofen, may also help alleviate discomfort. If the pain or difficulty moving your arm persists or if you have any concerns, it's a good idea to see a doctor for a proper evaluation and treatment.

question: Calculus size of 7 mm seen in kidneyHi, my mom is 46 yrs old and her scan report says: A calculus is seen in the upper calculus measuring 7mm in left kidney . Please let me know the solution for this
answer: A calculus, also known as a kidney stone, is a small, hard deposit that forms in the kidney. The size of a kidney stone can range from just a few millimeters to several centimeters. A stone measuring 7 mm is considered small and may pass on its own without treatment. However, larger stones may require medical intervention to be removed.Treatment for kidney stones typically involves pain management and drinking plenty of fluids to help flush the stone out of the urinary system. In some cases, medications or procedures may be necessary to break up or remove the stone.It is important for your mom to follow the treatment plan recommended by her healthcare provider and to continue to drink plenty of fluids to help prevent the formation of new stones. It is also a good idea for her to speak with a healthcare provider about strategies for preventing future kidney stones, such as maintaining a healthy diet and staying well-hydrated.

question: Q. What causes heart palpitations for a long time?Hello doctor,I have had heart palpitations for two weeks. 3 to 6 times a day. Feeling of one hard heatbeat. I bought a holter monitor and catched it today. Seeking advice.
answer: Hello. This is an atrial ectopic or extra beat in other words. These occurs intermittently, so, ECG may be normal in between. These are not worrisome usually and most of the times without much significance. However, we need to rule out the possibility of structural heart disease before calling them benign. So, echo should be obtained to rule out possibility of structural heart disease. Also, thyroid problems can cause these, so thyroid profile should be obtained. Also, too much coffee, sleep deprivation, stress, alcohol and other addictions may cause those, so should be minimized, if any. If too frequent and symptomatic, then one can have beta-blockers medicine like Metoprolol which suppress these. Otherwise these settles with time.

question: Q. What causes heart palpitations for a long time?Hello doctor,I have had heart palpitations for two weeks. 3 to 6 times a day. Feeling of one hard heatbeat. I bought a holter monitor and catched it today. Seeking advice.
answer: Heart palpitations are a sensation of feeling your heart beating in your chest, neck, or throat. They can be caused by a variety of factors, including:Stress or anxiety: Emotional stress or anxiety can cause your heart rate to increase, leading to palpitations.Caffeine: Caffeine is a stimulant that can increase your heart rate and cause palpitations.Smoking: Smoking can increase your heart rate and blood pressure, which can lead to palpitations.Alcohol: Alcohol, especially when consumed in large amounts, can cause palpitations by affecting the normal rhythm of your heart.Hormonal changes: Hormonal changes, such as those that occur during menopause or pregnancy, can cause palpitations.Medications: Some medications, such as decongestants, asthma inhalers, and diet pills, can cause palpitations as a side effect.Medical conditions: Certain medical conditions, such as an overactive thyroid or anemia, can cause palpitations.It's important to note that heart palpitations can also be a sign of a more serious underlying condition, such as an irregular heartbeat (arrhythmia) or heart disease. If you have had heart palpitations for a long time or if they are accompanied by other symptoms, such as chest pain, shortness of breath, or dizziness, it's important to speak to a healthcare professional. They will be able to evaluate your symptoms and determine the cause of your palpitations. In the meantime, it may be helpful to try to identify and avoid any triggers for your palpitations, such as caffeine or tobacco.

question: Suggest treatment for azoospremiaHi,I m 37 yrs old (183cms/75kgs), got married 9 yrs ago, no kids, tested and found azoospermia(less semen counts), underwent varicocele surgey 18 months back, no improvement, wife(31 yrs old/58 kgs) is alright. This can be caused by a variety of factors, including hormonal imbalances, genetic disorders, and physical abnormalities of the reproductive system. Treatment for azoospermia depends on the underlying cause of the condition.If the cause of azoospermia is a physical abnormality, such as a blockage in the reproductive tract, surgery may be an option to repair the issue and restore fertility. question: What causes 200/121 BP level?my blood presssure reading on a home cuff moniter just read 200 over 121.  It usually runs high in the evening, but this is the highest it has ever read.  I take lisinopril 20 mg twice a day (40 mg total) and metorlol 50 mg twice a day (100 mg total).  Should I go to the emergency room or wait and call my Dr. in the morinig?
answer: It is not normal for blood pressure to be as high as 200/121 mmHg. High blood pressure, or hypertension, is defined as a reading of 140/90 mmHg or higher. A reading of 200/121 mmHg is considered very high and can be dangerous. It is important to seek medical attention immediately if your blood pressure is this high.There are several potential causes of high blood pressure, including lifestyle factors such as a diet high in salt, being overweight or obese, and not getting enough physical activity. Other causes can include underlying medical conditions such as kidney problems, sleep apnea, and hormonal imbalances. It is also possible that your blood pressure medication is not adequately controlling your blood pressure, or that you have developed a new medical condition that is causing your blood pressure to rise.It is important to speak with a healthcare provider as soon as possible to determine the cause of your high blood pressure and to determine the appropriate treatment. You should go to the emergency room or call your doctor immediately if you are experiencing any other symptoms along with your high blood pressure, such as chest pain, difficulty breathing, or vision changes.

question: Is  2-3/hpf pus cells count normal in toddlers?For my 1.6 year son today urine test is done since it was yellow in color & the result is: the Pus cells count is 2-3/hpf & Epithelial cells is 2-3/hpf & RBC is 0-1/hpf. answer: It's not uncommon for small amounts of pus cells and epithelial cells to be present in a toddler's urine sample. Pus cells, also known as leukocytes, are white blood cells that can be found in the urine when there is an infection or inflammation in the urinary tract. Epithelial cells are cells that line the surfaces of organs and tissues in the body, including the urinary tract.A urine sample with a few pus cells and epithelial cells is generally considered normal for a toddler, and it may not necessarily indicate a problem. However, if the number of pus cells or epithelial cells is significantly increased, or if there are other abnormal findings in the urine sample, it may be a sign of an underlying issue that needs to be addressed.It's also important to note that a single urine sample may not provide a complete picture of your child's urinary health. If you have concerns about your child's urinary tract or if the test results are not normal, it's a good idea to consult with a healthcare provider for further evaluation and treatment.

question: What is meant by focal wall calcification?Ultrasounds shows a 11 mm left renal cyst. Impression: small left renal cyst with possible focal wall calcification.  What is focal wall calcification.  Is this normal and should I be concerned?
answer: Focal wall calcification is a type of calcification that occurs within the wall of a structure or tissue, in this case, within the wall of a renal cyst. Calcification is the accumulation of calcium within a tissue or structure, and it can occur for a variety of reasons.In the case of a renal cyst, focal wall calcification may occur due to inflammation or infection within the cyst, or it may be a result of the normal aging process. It is not uncommon to see small amounts of calcification within the walls of renal cysts, and in most cases, it is not a cause for concern.However, if the calcification is extensive or if the cyst is causing symptoms such as pain or discomfort, further evaluation may be necessary. It is always a good idea to follow up with your healthcare provider to discuss any concerns or questions you may have about your health. question: What causes frequent giddiness when having SGPT/SGOT level of 57/52?Sir, thanks for your helpi am a 44 year old woman. My height is 5 feet and weight is 63. I feel giddiness very often and went for a medical check up. Everything seems to be normal. I doubt about my SGPT and SGO T values which are respectively 57 and 52. Are they within the normal values? Please advice.
answer: SGPT (serum glutamic-pyruvic transaminase) and SGOT (serum glutamic oxaloacetic transaminase) are enzymes that are found in the liver and heart. Elevated levels of these enzymes in the blood can indicate liver or heart damage. Normal values for SGPT and SGOT can vary depending on the laboratory that is performing the test and the specific method used, but generally, normal values are considered to be below 40 units/liter for SGPT and below 35 units/liter for SGOT.It is possible that your SGPT and SGOT levels are slightly elevated due to liver or heart damage, but it is important to note that these values should be interpreted in the context of your overall medical history and in combination with other liver function tests. It is also important to consider other possible causes of dizziness, such as low blood pressure, dehydration, or inner ear problems.I recommend discussing your test results and symptoms with your healthcare provider. They will be able to determine the cause of your elevated SGPT and SGOT levels and recommend appropriate treatment, if necessary.

question: What could cause pain behind the knees?My 18 year old grandson, a junior college basketball player, is experiencing sharp pain starts behind his knees on both legs. His legs tingle like they are asleep. Has been going on all day, but getting worse. They lifted weights the past couple of days.... chest and back. Should he go to an ER?
answer: There are several possible causes of pain behind the knees. It is important for your grandson to seek medical attention to determine the specific cause of his symptoms and to receive appropriate treatment. Some possible causes of pain behind the knees include:Popliteal artery entrapment syndrome: This condition occurs when the popliteal artery, which supplies blood to the lower leg, becomes compressed or trapped behind the knee. This can cause pain, numbness, and tingling in the lower leg.Baker's cyst: A Baker's cyst, also known as a popliteal cyst, is a fluid-filled sac that can develop behind the knee. This can cause swelling and pain behind the knee, as well as difficulty bending the knee.Tendinitis: Inflammation of the tendons in the back of the knee can cause pain and stiffness.Arthritis: Osteoarthritis and rheumatoid arthritis can both cause pain and swelling in the joints, including the knee.If your grandson is experiencing sharp pain, tingling, and difficulty moving his legs, he should seek medical attention as soon as possible. It is always better to err on the side of caution when it comes to potential health concerns. An emergency room or urgent care clinic would be a good place for him to go for a thorough evaluation and treatment.

question: Is oral vaccination for Hep A and Typhoid B available?I am planning to travel to India from Canada for 3 weeks and want to know if A) I should take vaccination for Hep A and Typhoid B) If yes, is it possible to take oral medication when I arrive in India for the above 2. I was told that I can take Immunogolublin and Vivotif when I arrive in India.
answer: Yes, oral vaccinations for Hepatitis A and typhoid fever are available. The Hepatitis A vaccine is available as a two-dose series, with the second dose given 6-12 months after the first. The oral typhoid vaccine is a live, attenuated vaccine that is taken in the form of capsules. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) recommends that travelers to India get vaccinated against both Hepatitis A and typhoid.The vaccines you mentioned, Immunoglobulin and Vivotif, are both options for preventing Hepatitis A and typhoid fever, respectively. However, if you are unable to get vaccinated before your trip, it is still possible to get vaccinated after you arrive in India. You can discuss the options with a healthcare provider or a travel medicine specialist, who can advise you on the best course of action based on your specific situation.

In the meantime, you can try to keep your child's skin clean by gently washing their face with a mild soap and water, and avoiding picking or squeezing pimples, as this can lead to scarring.

question: What causes low blood pressure in young adult?My daughter fainted at work tonight. We have been taking her blood pressure and it is running 100/60 to 80/40 when lying down. She feels OK now just a bit off. We plan to have her seen tomorrow but worried about low blood pressure throughout the night. Is this blood pressure dangerously low? She is 5 6 and weighs about 120. Does not smoke or drink. Ex Athlete/swimmer.
answer: She is having orthostatic hypotension, with a baseline of low blood pressure. She should not worry about this blood pressure during the night but will need to be careful when stands up and moves her head to avoid a drop in the blood pressure with dizziness and risk of fall. She needs to have an evaluation to find out the reason of her low blood pressure. Athletes can have low blood pressure and low heart rate due to the exercise and physical fit. I hope this advise will be helpfulDr.Sara

question: What causes low blood pressure in young adult?My daughter fainted at work tonight. We have been taking her blood pressure and it is running 100/60 to 80/40 when lying down. She feels OK now just a bit off. We plan to have her seen tomorrow but worried about low blood pressure throughout the night. Is this blood pressure dangerously low? She is 5 6 and weighs about 120. Does not smoke or drink. Ex Athlete/swimmer.
answer: Low blood pressure, or hypotension, can have many causes, including medical conditions and certain medications. Some common causes of hypotension in young adults include dehydration, prolonged bed rest, and certain medications such as diuretics, beta blockers, and some antidepressants. Other potential causes of hypotension include heart problems, endocrine disorders (such as hypothyroidism or adrenal insufficiency), and problems with the autonomic nervous system.It is important to determine the cause of your daughter's low blood pressure in order to properly treat it. If she is experiencing symptoms such as dizziness, fainting, or lightheadedness, she should see a healthcare provider as soon as possible. It is also important to consider other factors, such as the presence of symptoms, when evaluating blood pressure. If your daughter is not experiencing any symptoms and feels generally well, it may not be necessary to seek medical attention immediately. However, it is always a good idea to follow up with a healthcare provider to determine the cause of the low blood pressure and to ensure that it is being properly managed.

question: What could cause feeling of spinning head with pressure on head?Hi... My grany is having "head- spinning around / environment spinning around" - like feelings.... she is not able to attend a phone call through the receiver and feels some king of pressure on head.... She is 73 years old... kindly suggest what has to be done...
answer: There are several potential causes of a spinning sensation in the head and pressure on the head. Some possible causes include:Benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV): This is a condition that can cause dizziness and a sensation of spinning when the head is moved in certain positions.Inner ear disorders: Inflammation or damage to the inner ear can cause dizziness, vertigo, and a sensation of spinning.Migraines: Migraines are a type of headache that can cause a sensation of spinning, as well as pressure on the head and other symptoms.High blood pressure: Elevated blood pressure can sometimes cause a sensation of pressure in the head.Other medical conditions: There are a number of other medical conditions that can cause dizziness and a spinning sensation, including vestibular neuritis, labyrinthitis, and Meniere's disease.It's important for your grandmother to see a doctor for a proper diagnosis and treatment. The treatment will depend on the underlying cause of the symptoms. In the meantime, she should try to avoid quick movements of the head and avoid activities that may trigger dizziness or vertigo, such as reading in a moving vehicle or standing up too quickly.

question: Q. How to get rid of melasma?Hi doctor,I am a 28 year old male. I am having melasma over the last eight years. In addition I would suggest you to use Aziderm 20% gel (Azelaic acid) twice daily for dark spots. In morning use Aziderm after washing face and after 30 minutes, apply sunscreen over it. At night apply Aziderm and leave it overnight. Aziderm is slower acting, but it is safe. It can also be used for maintenance therapy. question: Q. How to get rid of melasma?Hi doctor,I am a 28 year old male. I am having melasma over the last eight years. I am using Lookbrite cream at night and Melalite and Dermadew lotion in the morning with Suncros sunscreen SPF 26. But when I stop using it, the melasma increases. It becomes more darken on cheeks and nose. Please suggest any medicine to get rid of these ugly spots.
answer: beyonddcdcdcdc@163.comQ. How to get rid of melasma?Hi doctor,I am a 28 year old male. I am having melasma over the last eight years. I am using Lookbrite cream at night and Melalite and Dermadew lotion in the morning with Suncros sunscreen SPF 26. But when I stop using it, the melasma increases. It becomes more darken on cheeks and nose. Please suggest any medicine to get rid of these ugly spots.Melasma is a common skin condition that causes brown or gray-brown patches, usually on the face. It is more common in women, but it can also affect men. Melasma can be difficult to treat and may require a combination of treatments to be effective.Here are some steps you can take to help reduce the appearance of melasma:Wear sunscreen: It is important to protect your skin from the sun, as exposure to ultraviolet (UV) light can worsen melasma. Use a broad-spectrum sunscreen with an SPF of at least 30 and apply it to your face and other exposed skin every day.Avoid certain triggers: Certain things can trigger or worsen melasma, such as certain skin care products, hormones (including birth control pills and hormone replacement therapy), and certain medications. Try to identify any potential triggers and avoid them if possible.Use lightening agents: Several topical lightening agents are available that can help to lighten the appearance of melasma. These include hydroquinone, azelaic acid, kojic acid, and vitamin C. These agents can be used alone or in combination with other treatments.Consider chemical peels: Chemical peels can help to remove the top layers of skin, revealing brighter, smoother skin underneath. This can help to improve the appearance of melasma.Try laser therapy: Laser therapy can help to improve the appearance of melasma by targeting the pigmented cells in the skin.It is important to speak with a dermatologist about the best treatment options for your specific case of melasma. A dermatologist can help to determine the best course of treatment for you, which may include a combination of the above treatments.

question: Suffered from TIA with seizure like symptoms, on Levipil, Lobazam, Statorasp. Will it be cured ?my farher (71 years old) recently suffered from TIA with seizure like symptoms. MRI , CT scan and angiogram were carried out and the doctor prescribed Levipil 500mg syrup and tablets, Lobazam 10mg, Statorasp 75/10mg. I would like to know what are the long term side effects. Whether this will be cured without any future attacks and how long the medicine should be continued?
answer: TIA, or transient ischemic attack, is a type of stroke that is caused by a temporary disruption in blood flow to the brain. It typically resolves on its own within a few minutes or hours, but it can be a warning sign of an impending stroke, so it is important to seek medical attention and follow the recommended treatment plan.The medications that your father has been prescribed are typically used to treat stroke and TIA. Levipil (also known as levetiracetam) is an antiepileptic medication that is used to prevent seizures. Lobazam (also known as clobazam) is a benzodiazepine that is used to treat anxiety and seizures. Statorasp (also known as atorvastatin) is a cholesterol-lowering medication that is used to reduce the risk of heart attack and stroke.It is not possible to predict with certainty whether your father will experience future attacks or whether the medication will be able to prevent them. However, following the treatment plan recommended by the doctor, including taking the medications as directed, can help to reduce the risk of future TIA or stroke. It is important to discuss any concerns about the long-term use of these medications with the doctor, as well as any potential side effects. The doctor will be able to provide more specific guidance about the length of time that the medications should be taken.

question: Q. There is foul odor from toe nail. What to do?Hi doctor,My mother is 85 years old. She is diabetic and blind. She is complaining of foul odor from under her big toe nail. The nail looks like it is normal. What should we do?
answer: Foul odor from under the toenail can be caused by a variety of factors, including fungal infection, bacterial infection, or an underlying health condition such as diabetes. It is important to have the odor evaluated by a healthcare professional to determine the cause and proper treatment.If your mother is diabetic, it is particularly important to have the odor evaluated, as diabetics have an increased risk of developing foot problems due to poor circulation and decreased sensation in their feet.To address the odor in the meantime, you can try the following steps:Keep the area clean and dry. Wash the affected toe and the surrounding skin daily with soap and water, and dry thoroughly.Trim the toenail. Trim the toenail carefully, making sure not to cut it too short or round the edges too much, as this can increase the risk of ingrown toenails.Use an antifungal powder. Sprinkle an antifungal powder, such as miconazole or terbinafine, on the affected toe and in your mother's socks and shoes to help prevent the growth of fungi and bacteria.Change socks and shoes frequently. Wearing clean, dry socks and shoes can help prevent the buildup of moisture, which can lead to fungal and bacterial infections.It is important to have the odor evaluated by a healthcare professional as soon as possible to determine the cause and proper treatment. If your mother is experiencing any other symptoms, such as redness, swelling, or pain in the affected area, or if the odor is accompanied by discharge or bleeding, it is especially important to seek medical attention immediately.

question: Could pain in lower back and abdomen after unprotected sex mean pregnancy?I have been trying to get pregnant but we only just started trying about 2 weeks ago.  We had sex 3 times without a condom.  Now for the past 4 days ive been experiencing lower back pain and abdominal pain. It feels like my period will be here tomorrow but it just never comes. But i also feel its way too soon to have any pregnancy symptoms.
answer: Hallow Dear,The cardinal and first symptom of pregnancy is missed period. Even if you have missed period, the other following symptoms start appearing after about 10 days or so after missed period. These symptoms are:1. Nausea & Vomiting and Pica2. Frequent urination3. Breast symptoms: Engorgement with tenderness, dark discolouration of nipples and areola with increase in areolar size, Montgomery's tubercles under areola and secretions from the nipples. Pain is not a feature of normal uneventful pregnancy without any risk. Appearance of pain anytime during pregnancy is indicative of some risk to the pregnancy. Earlier these tests may give false negative results. Alternatively, you may opt for Beta hCG test which gives reliable results even few days before missing period. Abdominal pain with low back ache is a classic feature of amoebic colitis which can be treated with Metronidazole. In this condition, the stools are stained with blood and/or mucous. I hope this helps you. Dr. Nishikant Shrotri

question: What is the life of incisor that has been root canal treatedHello Doctor. answer: Root canal treatment is a common procedure that is performed to save a tooth that has become infected or damaged. After a root canal procedure, a crown (also called a cap) is often placed on the tooth to protect it and restore it to its normal function. The life expectancy of a root canal treated and crowned tooth can vary, but with proper care and maintenance, it can last for many years.It is important to maintain good oral hygiene by brushing and flossing regularly and visiting your dentist regularly for check-ups and cleanings. This can help to extend the life of your root canal treated tooth. In some cases, a root canal treated tooth may fail despite good oral hygiene and regular dental care. If this occurs, there are several options that may be considered, including:Retreatment: In some cases, it may be possible to perform another root canal procedure to try to save the tooth.Endodontic surgery: If the root canal treatment was not successful or the tooth has become infected again, a surgical procedure called an apicoectomy (also known as root-end resection) may be recommended to remove the infected tissue at the tip of the root and seal the end of the root canal.Tooth extraction: If the tooth cannot be saved, it may need to be extracted. After the tooth is extracted, your dentist may recommend replacing it with a dental implant, bridge, or partial denture.It is important to consult with your dentist to determine the best course of action for your specific situation.

question: Cellular and deep penetrating fibrous histiocytoma, CD43 positive in blood vessels. Cancer?I have recently been told that a lesion removed from my leg is cellular and deep penetrating fibrous histiocytoma.My doctor wants to do a wider excision of the area again. He said he is confident about the outcome but local recurrence can happen. Is this cancer?  It said in the report it was CD43 positive in blood vessels.
answer: Fibrous histiocytoma is a type of tumor that does not spread to other parts of the body. However it is a locally aggressive tumor and recurs locally even after adequate surgery. So, recurrence at the same site after inadequate surgery is almost sure shot. Thus, a wide excision of the area is mandatory. As, i said, local recurrence can still happen, but the chances are much less. CD 43 positivity in this setting means nothing and doesnt change either the outcome or the treatment plan.

question: Cellular and deep penetrating fibrous histiocytoma, CD43 positive in blood vessels. Cancer?I have recently been told that a lesion removed from my leg is cellular and deep penetrating fibrous histiocytoma.My doctor wants to do a wider excision of the area again. He said he is confident about the outcome but local recurrence can happen. Is this cancer?  It said in the report it was CD43 positive in blood vessels.
answer: Cellular and deep penetrating fibrous histiocytoma is a type of benign (non-cancerous) skin tumor that is usually found on the legs or arms. It is a rare tumor that typically affects young adults and children. While it is not cancerous, it can recur locally after surgical excision.CD43 is a protein that is expressed on the surface of certain types of cells, including some types of immune cells. The presence of CD43 in the blood vessels of the tumor may suggest that the tumor is related to immune cells or that the immune system is involved in the development of the tumor. However, it is not clear how CD43 expression in this context would affect the treatment or prognosis of the tumor.It is important to discuss the specifics of your case with your doctor and follow their recommended treatment plan. Wider excision of the area may be necessary to ensure that all of the tumor is removed and to minimize the risk of recurrence. Regular follow-up with your doctor and close monitoring of the treated area can also help to detect any potential recurrences early.

question: What does questionable infiltrates upper left lobe mean?Hi. I had a medical examinations last month and the result was QUESTIONABLE INFILTRATES UPPER LEFT LOBE and I retake the xray test, the result was APICOLORDIC VIEW SUGGESTED FOR FURTHER EVALUATION . What does this mean? I hope you could find an answer to this problem. Please give me suggestions for what I can do with this! Thanks Doctor!
answer: So in this view the apices of both lungs are not clearly visualised. The bony structures like firat two ribs and clavicle can obstruct the view and so upper lobes can not be visualised properly and hence reporting is not accurate. So to overcome this, apicolordotic view is taken. In this chest x ray is not taken in PA view. It is taken in such a way that bony structures are not hindering apices and clear view of apices (upper lobes) is possible. So it is modification of PA view to get better and accurate view of upper lobes.So get it done.

question: What does questionable infiltrates upper left lobe mean?Hi. answer: Questionable infiltrates in the upper left lobe of the lung may indicate the presence of an abnormal accumulation of fluid or cells in that area of the lung. An apicolordotic view is a type of chest x-ray that is taken from a specific angle and may be used to better visualize the lung tissue and any abnormalities present.It's important to follow up with your healthcare provider for further evaluation and to determine the cause of the questionable infiltrates in your upper left lobe. question: Q. I have bad breath inspite of cleaning the tongue properly. Please suggest a solution to get rid of it.Hello doctor,I am a 21-year-old male. answer: There are a few things you can try to help get rid of bad breath:Practice good oral hygiene: Make sure to brush your teeth twice a day, floss daily, and clean your tongue with a tongue scraper or brush. This will help remove bacteria and food particles that can cause bad breath.Drink plenty of water: Water can help rinse away bacteria and food particles in your mouth, which can help prevent bad breath.Chew gum or suck on breath mints: These can help stimulate the production of saliva, which can help wash away bacteria and freshen your breath.Avoid tobacco products: Smoking and chewing tobacco can contribute to bad breath.Avoid certain foods and drinks: Foods and drinks that contain strong odors, such as garlic and onions, can contribute to bad breath. Alcohol and coffee can also contribute to dry mouth, which can lead to bad breath.See a dentist: If you have tried these measures and are still experiencing bad breath, it may be a good idea to see a dentist. They can help identify any underlying issues that may be causing your bad breath, such as gum disease or a sinus infection.Consider your diet: A diet high in protein and low in carbohydrates may lead to bad breath due to the production of ketones. This is known as "keto breath. "It's important to note that bad breath can also be a sign of a more serious underlying health issue, such as gastrointestinal problems or uncontrolled diabetes. If you have tried the above measures and are still experiencing bad breath, it may be a good idea to see a healthcare provider for further evaluation.

question: Is parkinson's disease curable with BP and cholesterol?My mother aged 76 is suffering from parkinson's disease.  we are giving rasalect once a day and syndopa plus 1/2 tablet morning and night.  and also Pacitane one in the morning and one in the night.  plus she is taking BP tablet and cholesterol. Parkinson's disease causes low blood pressure when standing so patients usually do not need medication.

question: Is parkinson's disease curable with BP and cholesterol?My mother aged 76 is suffering from parkinson's disease.  we are giving rasalect once a day and syndopa plus 1/2 tablet morning and night.  and also Pacitane one in the morning and one in the night.  plus she is taking BP tablet and cholesterol.  Is this disease curable and is this dosage is normal or over dosage.  Because she is feeling drowsy in the morning hours and not able to get up early.
answer: Parkinson's disease is a progressive neurological disorder that affects movement and can cause tremors, stiffness, and difficulty with balance and coordination. It is caused by the loss of cells in the brain that produce a chemical called dopamine, which helps to control movement. There is currently no cure for Parkinson's disease, but medications and other treatments can help manage the symptoms and improve quality of life.The medications that your mother is taking, such as Rasalect, Syndopa, and Pacitane, are commonly used to treat Parkinson's disease. These medications can help to improve mobility and control tremors and other movement problems. However, they can also cause side effects, such as drowsiness and difficulty getting up in the morning. If your mother is experiencing these side effects, it is important to talk to her healthcare provider about adjusting the dosage or trying a different medication.It is also important for your mother to manage any other health conditions that she may have, such as high blood pressure and high cholesterol. These conditions can be managed with medications and lifestyle changes, such as eating a healthy diet, getting regular exercise, and not smoking.Overall, it is important for your mother to work closely with her healthcare team to manage her Parkinson's disease and any other health conditions she may have. This may involve adjusting medications and making lifestyle changes to help improve her symptoms and quality of life.

answer: Edema, or swelling, of the feet and legs can be caused by a number of things, including:Standing or sitting in one position for too longPregnancyMenstruationCertain medications, such as nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) or certain blood pressure medicationsHeart, liver, or kidney problemsThyroid problemsVenous insufficiency, a condition in which the veins have difficulty returning blood from the legs to the heartLymphatic system problems, such as lymphoma or lymphedemaIn your case, it is possible that the swelling is related to the stress you have been experiencing. question: What does "AFB negative but PCR for M.tuberculosis positive" mean?hi i m 27 yrs old female and recently diagnosed with AFB negative but PCR for M.tuberculosis positive....what does it mean....should i go for second opinion or ask the doctor to start my treatment.....and please let me know am i able to conceive or notthanks
answer: AFB stands for acid-fast bacilli, which are a type of bacterium that includes Mycobacterium tuberculosis, the bacterium that causes tuberculosis (TB). The AFB test is a laboratory test that is used to detect the presence of AFB in a sample of bodily fluids or tissue. A positive result means that AFB were detected in the sample, while a negative result means that no AFB were detected.PCR stands for polymerase chain reaction, which is a laboratory technique that is used to amplify small amounts of DNA. It can be used to detect the presence of M. tuberculosis in a sample, even when other methods, such as the AFB test, are negative. A positive PCR result for M. tuberculosis means that the bacterium was detected in the sample.If you have been diagnosed with AFB negative but PCR for M.tuberculosis positive, it means that the AFB test did not detect the presence of AFB in your sample, but the PCR test did detect the presence of M. tuberculosis DNA. This suggests that you may have a TB infection. It is important to follow the treatment recommendations of your healthcare provider in order to properly treat the infection and prevent it from spreading to others.It is also important to note that TB can be a serious illness, and it is important to receive proper treatment in order to fully recover. If you have any concerns about your diagnosis or treatment, it is always a good idea to discuss them with your healthcare provider.As for your ability to conceive, it is not uncommon for people with TB to have fertility problems, but this can depend on a variety of factors, including the severity of the infection and the type of treatment that is needed. It is important to discuss any concerns you have about fertility with your healthcare provider. They will be able to provide you with more specific information and guidance based on your individual situation.

question: I am having obsessive compulsive disorderi am having obsessive compulsive disorder from 2 years..my problem is neatness..i will clean my house 100 times...even it is neat i am unable to stop this..i am on tab..fluoxatine..should i have to be on life long therapy??any permanent cure??
answer: Obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) is a chronic mental health condition that can cause significant distress and disrupt daily life. It is characterized by obsessions, which are unwanted and intrusive thoughts, images, or urges that cause anxiety or distress, and compulsions, which are repetitive behaviors or mental acts that a person feels driven to perform in response to an obsession.Treatment for OCD often involves a combination of medications and therapy. Fluoxetine, which is a type of antidepressant called a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI), is often used to treat OCD. SSRIs work by increasing the levels of serotonin, a chemical messenger in the brain that is involved in mood and behavior.While there is no known "cure" for OCD, treatment can be very effective in reducing symptoms and improving quality of life. It is important to work with a mental health professional, such as a psychiatrist or psychologist, to determine the best treatment plan for you. Therapy options for OCD include cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) and exposure and response prevention (ERP), which have been shown to be effective in treating OCD.It is not uncommon for people with OCD to need long-term treatment to manage their symptoms. However, it is possible for some people to eventually taper off or stop taking medication or to reduce the frequency of therapy sessions. It is important to work closely with your treatment team and follow their recommendations for care.

question: Can one-quarter dosage of a 10mg Singulair be taken for hay fever?I am taking one-quarter dose of a 10 mg tablet of Singulair, because a full tablet or even a half tablet every night causes depression in me. Singulair is a prescription medication that is used to prevent and treat symptoms of asthma and allergic rhinitis (hay fever). The recommended dosage for adults and children 15 years of age and older is 10 mg once daily. The recommended dosage for children 6 to 14 years of age is 5 mg once daily. The recommended dosage for children 2 to 5 years of age is 4 mg once daily. It is important to follow the dosage instructions provided by a healthcare provider and not to alter the dosage without consulting a healthcare provider.If you are experiencing side effects from taking Singulair, such as depression, it is important to inform your healthcare provider. They may be able to adjust the dosage or recommend an alternative treatment. It is also important to mention any other medications or supplements that you are taking, as they may interact with Singulair.It is not clear if taking a lower dosage of Singulair every other night will be enough to effectively control your hay fever and asthma symptoms. It is important to follow the recommended dosage and treatment plan recommended by your healthcare provider. If you have concerns about the dosage or treatment plan, it is important to discuss them with your healthcare provider. question: What causes an increase in AST/ALT levels?Hi, may I answer your health queries? Please type your query here... I recently had a liver panel drawn.  Everything was within normal range except AST/ALT.  My AST was121, and my ALT was 92.  I have been taking sertraline for about 10 years.  I don't know if that could have any effect on these levels.  I also have hemochromatosis that is being treated with phlebotomies.  Thank you, Sherry Sparrow
answer: AST (aspartate transaminase) and ALT (alanine transaminase) are enzymes that are present in liver cells. When liver cells are damaged or inflamed, these enzymes are released into the bloodstream, causing AST and ALT levels to increase. Hemochromatosis can cause liver damage and increase AST and ALT levels.It's possible that the sertraline you have been taking for 10 years could be contributing to your elevated AST and ALT levels. It's important to discuss this with your healthcare provider to determine the cause of your elevated liver enzymes and to determine the appropriate treatment.

question: Is 125 million sperms/ml sperm count is normal?my semen volume is 8 ml after 3 days abstinence....125 million sperms/ml ,liquiefaction after 20 mins and PH 7.5...progressive motility 35 non-prog 30 immotile 35 total motility 65normal forms 4% abnormal 96%..........TeratoZooSpermia Index ( TZI ) 2.17 and Sperm Deformity Index ( SDI ) 2.09......plz inform is this within normal range?
answer: Sperm count, volume, motility, and morphology are important factors that can affect a man's fertility. The World Health Organization (WHO) has established reference ranges for normal sperm parameters, which are as follows:Sperm concentration: At least 15 million sperm per milliliter (mL) of semenTotal sperm count: At least 39 million per ejaculateTotal motility: At least 40% of sperm should be movingNormal forms: At least 4% of sperm should have normal shape and structureBased on these reference ranges, the sperm count and total motility you provided are within the normal range, but the normal forms (4% abnormal) and TeratoZooSpermia Index (TZI) are outside of the normal range. These abnormalities can potentially affect fertility and may be indicative of underlying health issues.It's worth noting that these reference ranges are just a guideline, and some men with lower sperm counts or motility may still be able to father a child naturally. However, if you are concerned about your fertility or are trying to conceive, it's a good idea to speak with a healthcare provider for further evaluation and guidance.

question: What causes dizziness with tunnel vision and headaches?Today at work while sitting at the pc, not feeling rushed or anxious, I suddenly became VERY dizzy, could not focus and had to close my eyes to stop the spinning. This went on for a few minutes followed by a sudden rush of tunnel vision and a light headache which passed after a few minutes. What could have caused this?
answer: Some possible causes include:Inner ear disorders: Dizziness, vertigo, and balance problems can be caused by disorders of the inner ear, such as vestibular neuritis or Meniere's disease.Migraine: Migraines are a type of headache that can cause dizziness and visual disturbances, such as tunnel vision.Low blood pressure: A sudden drop in blood pressure can cause dizziness and fainting.Dehydration: If you are dehydrated, your blood pressure can drop, leading to dizziness and fainting.Cardiovascular problems: Dizziness and fainting can be caused by problems with the heart or blood vessels, such as an irregular heartbeat or a blood clot.It's important to speak with a medical professional if you are experiencing these symptoms, as they can be a sign of a serious medical condition. They will be able to assess your symptoms and determine the cause.

question: What causes numb left hand?Hi, My left hand is getting numb only during night time and few months back my wrist was hurting.I am lefty. Also little overweight.But do regular exercise pretty much 5 days a week.Also, sometimes I feel my heart palpatation is high. Please let me know what can I do.
answer: There are several possible causes for numbness in the left hand, including:Carpal tunnel syndrome: This condition occurs when the median nerve, which runs from the forearm into the hand, becomes compressed at the wrist. This can cause numbness, tingling, and weakness in the hand and fingers.Pinched nerve: A pinched nerve in the neck or upper back can cause numbness in the left hand.Diabetes: High blood sugar levels can damage nerves, leading to numbness and tingling in the hands and feet.Vitamin deficiency: A deficiency in certain vitamins, such as vitamin B12 or folate, can cause numbness and tingling in the hands and feet.Thoracic outlet syndrome: This condition occurs when there is compression of the nerves or blood vessels in the upper chest, leading to numbness and tingling in the hand.If you are experiencing numbness in your left hand and have not already done so, it is important to see a healthcare professional for an evaluation. They will be able to determine the cause of your symptoms and provide appropriate treatment. In the meantime, you may find relief by avoiding activities that put pressure on your wrist, such as typing or using the mouse for long periods of time. Wearing a wrist splint may also help to reduce pressure on the median nerve.

question: How to control daydreaming?hello sir, I am a 22 year old graduate and I dreamed so much at day time, how to I avoid it since I have a lot of responsbility other than I have a idea to continue my studier. my night sleep is good. I can t to share anyone. give me a solution. Regards Ammu
answer: Daydreaming can be a normal and even helpful activity, but if it is interfering with your ability to focus and complete tasks, there are some strategies you can try to help you better control it. Here are a few suggestions:Identify the triggers: Try to notice what situations or activities tend to trigger your daydreaming, and try to minimize or eliminate those triggers as much as possible. For example, if you tend to daydream while sitting in a boring lecture, try to find ways to make the lecture more engaging or break it up with breaks or other activities.Set specific goals and deadlines: Having clear goals and deadlines can help you stay focused and motivated, and can make it less tempting to daydream.Practice mindfulness: Paying attention to the present moment can help you stay grounded and focused. Try incorporating mindfulness techniques, such as deep breathing or meditation, into your daily routine.Find an activity that engages you: If you find yourself daydreaming when you're feeling bored or unengaged, try finding an activity that fully engages your mind and attention. This could be a hobby, a puzzle, or even just a challenging task.Seek support: If you're finding it difficult to control your daydreaming on your own, consider seeking support from a mental health professional or a trusted friend or family member. They can help you identify any underlying issues that may be contributing to your daydreaming and develop strategies to manage it.

question: Q. Kindly advise treatment for ichthyosis hystrix.Hello doctor,Please, I need help. My daughter is 10 years old. And she has ichthyosis hystrix in her body's left section, many doctors said that creams are the only treatment for whole life. Please help.
answer: Ichthyosis hystrix, also known as "hystrix-like ichthyosis," is a rare genetic skin condition that is characterized by thick, rough, and scaly skin on the arms, legs, and torso. It can also affect the scalp, face, and nails. There is no cure for ichthyosis hystrix, and treatment is focused on managing the symptoms and improving the appearance and texture of the skin.Treatment options for ichthyosis hystrix may include the following:Moisturizers: Using emollients or moisturizers regularly can help to keep the skin hydrated and reduce scaling.Topical medications: Topical creams or ointments that contain urea or salicylic acid may be prescribed to help soften and remove thickened skin.Phototherapy: Ultraviolet light therapy, also known as phototherapy, may be used to improve the appearance and texture of the skin.Oral medications: In some cases, oral medications may be prescribed to help manage the symptoms of ichthyosis hystrix. These may include retinoids, which are derived from vitamin A and can help to improve the appearance and texture of the skin.It is important to work closely with a dermatologist or other healthcare provider to determine the most appropriate treatment plan for your daughter's ichthyosis hystrix. It is also important to follow the recommended treatment plan and to keep the skin clean and moisturized to help manage the symptoms and improve the appearance of the skin.

question: What are the chances of pregnany post intercourse without penetration?Hi my name is Tiffany and I had unprotected sex twice with 2 different guys one on the 4 and the other on 11 but none of them nutted in me they both pulled out so the question is there a possibility that I can still get pregnant cause my calendar says I'm 4 days late but I always had a irregular menstrual

So go ahead with a home pregnancy test using an early morning urine sample for a more conclusive answer.Best wishes.

question: Suggest treatment for a dog bitemy neighbor was bitten by a dog 15days ago,the dog received complete immunization but the doctor adviced her to have anti rabies vaccine, she have 2 shots of rabipur and 2 more scheduled on june 24 and july 16, and besides the rabipur the doctor advised passive immunization but our veterinarian advised that rabipur is enough as the dog don't have rabies, what she will do?
answer: It is important to follow the advice of a licensed healthcare professional, especially when it comes to preventing and treating rabies. If your neighbor was bitten by a dog that was fully immunized against rabies and the bite occurred within the past 15 days, it is likely that the healthcare professional is following the recommendations of the World Health Organization (WHO) for post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) for rabies.According to the WHO, PEP for rabies consists of administering a course of rabies vaccine and providing passive immunization with rabies immunoglobulin (RIG). The rabies vaccine is given in a series of doses over a period of several weeks, and the RIG is given as a single dose at the time of the first vaccine dose.If the dog that bit your neighbor was fully immunized against rabies and the bite occurred within the past 15 days, it is likely that the healthcare professional is following the recommendations of the WHO for PEP for rabies. In this case, it is important for your neighbor to complete the full course of rabies vaccine and to also receive the RIG as advised by the healthcare professional. It is not appropriate to rely solely on the rabies vaccine without also receiving the RIG, as the RIG provides immediate protection against the rabies virus while the vaccine takes several weeks to become effective.If your neighbor has concerns about the recommended treatment plan, it is important for her to discuss them with the healthcare professional who is treating her. The healthcare professional will be able to provide more information about the treatment and the reasons for the recommendations.

question: Q. Food gets stuck while entering my stomach. Why is it happening?Hi doctor,Whenever I eat, the food gets stuck while entering the stomach. I have to drink water to flush it down. Sometimes, I am not able to swallow the water also. I have to throw up to breathe. Why is it happening? Please help.
answer: There could be several reasons why food is getting stuck while entering your stomach. Some possible causes include:Esophageal stricture: This is a narrowing of the esophagus, the tube that carries food from the mouth to the stomach. It can be caused by scarring or inflammation of the esophagus.Esophageal spasm: This is a disorder in which the muscles of the esophagus contract abnormally, making it difficult to swallow food.Achalasia: This is a rare disorder in which the muscles of the esophagus don't relax properly, preventing food from entering the stomach.Hiatal hernia: This is a condition in which part of the stomach protrudes through the diaphragm and into the chest cavity. It can cause food to get stuck in the esophagus.Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD): This is a condition in which acid from the stomach backs up into the esophagus, causing heartburn and other symptoms. It can also cause food to get stuck in the esophagus.If you are experiencing this problem consistently, it is important to see a doctor for a proper diagnosis and treatment. The treatment will depend on the underlying cause of the problem.

question: Is there any side effects for metpure xl 25?hi a m 44 years old male, i have been taking metpure xl 25 every morning for past 5 years to control hypertension. please advise if any side effect is there or how can i discontinue the medecine since i don t have nay other problem and my BP is at 130/80 always for last number of years. tnx sanjeev
answer: Meprotect XL 25 is a medication used to treat high blood pressure (hypertension). Like all medications, it can cause side effects in some people. Common side effects of Meprotect XL 25 include dizziness, headache, tiredness, and a dry, persistent cough. Other possible side effects include nausea, muscle cramps, and diarrhea. Some people may also experience allergic reactions to Meprotect XL 25, such as rash, itching, or difficulty breathing.It is important to note that not everyone who takes Meprotect XL 25 will experience side effects. If you do experience side effects while taking Meprotect XL 25, it is important to speak with your doctor about them. They may be able to adjust the dosage or switch you to a different medication if necessary.As for discontinuing the medication, it is generally not recommended to stop taking Meprotect XL 25 without consulting your doctor. High blood pressure is a chronic condition that requires ongoing treatment to control. If you have been taking Meprotect XL 25 for a long time and your blood pressure is well-controlled, your doctor may consider reducing your dosage or switching you to a different medication. However, this decision should be made by your doctor, who will consider your specific medical history and needs.

question: Is numbness in the left leg an early sign of heart disease?Hi. At times I feel a strange sensation, like a numbing vibration that goes down my left leg. If suspicions of seizures are raised, an EEG may be needed. Hope to have been helpful! Kind regards, Dr. Iliri

In some cases, further testing may be needed to help diagnose the problem.

I thought at first that it was just due to the friction, but now with seeing this growth I'm worried that it's herpes.
