question: Would bruising the 5th metatarsal require surgery?Hi my name is Andrea, last Wednesday I was standing on my desk so I could paint a quote on my wall and went for my chair and missed. Fell off and hit the side of my right foot on the metal part. I went to the doctor and he said I hurt my 5th metatarsal and I went back today because it still hurts and the doctor said I badly bruised it. Im just worried I will need surgery help!!!!
answer: It is possible that you may have bruised your fifth metatarsal, which is a bone in your foot that extends from your ankle to your toes. Bruising can occur when the soft tissues (such as muscles, tendons, and ligaments) are damaged by a blow or impact. It is usually not necessary to have surgery for a bruised metatarsal, as the injury typically heals on its own over time. However, if you are experiencing severe pain or if the injury is not improving after a few days, it may be necessary to consult with a healthcare provider or specialist to determine the appropriate course of treatment. In the meantime, you can try using ice and over-the-counter pain medication, elevating your foot, and resting as much as possible to help manage the pain and promote healing.

question: What causes pain from thighs to calf?I get excruciating pain emaniting from the top of my thigh going right down to the calf of my right foot.This happens particularly after walking a while or simply standing.sometimes it goes away after a brisk walk.i get numbness in my toes while sleeping at night & have continuous pain in my right foot while asleep.i have a fused L5 n a slight problem in L3/L4
answer: Radiating pain in leg may be attributed to sciatica where nerves are impinged in between their route. Try having some physiotherapy done and exercises do help. Don't do extreme range of movements at knee or hip. And use lumber corset while travelling. Harsh Swarup

question: What causes pain from thighs to calf?I get excruciating pain emaniting from the top of my thigh going right down to the calf of my right foot.This happens particularly after walking a while or simply standing.sometimes it goes away after a brisk walk.i get numbness in my toes while sleeping at night & have continuous pain in my right foot while asleep.i have a fused L5 n a slight problem in L3/L4
answer: There are several possible causes of pain that radiates from the top of the thigh to the calf of the foot. Some possible causes include:Sciatica: This is a type of nerve pain that occurs when the sciatic nerve, which runs from the lower back down the leg, becomes compressed or irritated. Sciatica can cause pain, numbness, and tingling in the thigh and calf.Musculoskeletal issues: Pain in the thigh and calf can also be caused by problems with the muscles, tendons, or bones in the leg. For example, a muscle strain or tendonitis in the thigh or calf could cause pain.Peripheral artery disease (PAD): This condition occurs when there is a blockage in the arteries that carry blood to the legs. PAD can cause pain, numbness, and weakness in the legs, especially when walking or standing.Other medical conditions: There are several other medical conditions that can cause pain in the thigh and calf, such as a blood clot in the leg (deep vein thrombosis), nerve damage (neuropathy), or arthritis.It's important to see a healthcare provider for a proper diagnosis and treatment plan. They will be able to determine the cause of your pain and recommend appropriate treatment options.

question: Feel weak and shaky, after drinking caffeine. Is it a caffeine allergy?I hear of caffine alergies but that s not my case. I heard of feeling week or shaky a few hours after drinking caffine but still not my case. My muscles don t all feel like the same. But rather soft. And yes. i feel shaky. but this is after only 10-20 min. After drinking something with caffine in it. Why does this happen?
answer: It's possible that you are experiencing caffeine intoxication, which can occur when you consume too much caffeine or are sensitive to caffeine. Symptoms of caffeine intoxication can include tremors, rapid heartbeat, muscle twitching, and weakness. It can also cause digestive problems, such as nausea and vomiting.Caffeine is a stimulant that can affect your central nervous system and increase your heart rate and blood pressure. If you consume too much caffeine, it can lead to caffeine intoxication, which can cause the symptoms you are experiencing.It's important to be aware of your caffeine intake and how your body reacts to it. If you are sensitive to caffeine or have a history of anxiety or other health conditions that could be exacerbated by caffeine, it may be best to limit your intake or avoid caffeine altogether. If you continue to experience symptoms after consuming caffeine, it may be a good idea to speak with a healthcare professional for further guidance.

question: Is rise in pressure from 116/66 to 140/80 normal?I have PAD and am on 40mg of Lisinopril a day. I have been taking 1/2 of that some days as my blood pressure has been dropping giving me a quick feeling of faintness and I am tired a lot of the time. My pressure today was 116/66 then within an hour was up to 140/80 then later dropped again. Is this normal?
answer: They are related to physical or emotional activity. Isolated blood pressure are not conclusive for high blood pressure. Some blood lab tests may be needed to exclude other possible causes of blood pressure fluctuations: - complete blood count- blood electrolytes for possible imbalance- thyroid hormone levels for possible thyroid dysfunction- inflammation tests (PCR, sedimentation rate). Hope you will find this answer helpful!Kind regards, Dr. Iliri

question: Is rise in pressure from 116/66 to 140/80 normal?I have PAD and am on 40mg of Lisinopril a day. I have been taking 1/2 of that some days as my blood pressure has been dropping giving me a quick feeling of faintness and I am tired a lot of the time. My pressure today was 116/66 then within an hour was up to 140/80 then later dropped again. Is this normal?
answer: It's not uncommon for blood pressure to fluctuate throughout the day, and a single reading may not necessarily reflect your overall blood pressure. However, a significant increase in blood pressure such as the one you described could be a cause for concern, especially if you have peripheral artery disease (PAD) and are taking lisinopril to manage your blood pressure. It's important to discuss this change in your blood pressure with your healthcare provider, as they may need to adjust your medication or recommend lifestyle changes to help manage your blood pressure. They may also want to monitor your blood pressure more closely to see if there are any patterns or underlying issues that need to be addressed. In the meantime, it's important to continue taking your medication as prescribed and to follow any other recommendations your healthcare provider may have for managing your blood pressure.
